I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The  additional  financing  is  needed  to  support  critical  water  supply  and  sanitation 
investments for the ongoing project which were part of the original feasibility study and investment 
plan conducted by the Cities Development Initiative for Asia (CDIA) but not included due to limited 
funds1. In particular, the project will finance: (i) the rehabilitation of water supply network in the 
remaining 12 district metered areas  established in the Shomansur district under the ongoing 
project and construct additional facilities at water source locations (wells, pumping stations) as 
well as rehabilitation of existing reservoir, and (ii) replacement of further portions of the main 
sewerage pipeline (Ayni and Muhammad collectors) and expansion of the network to unserved 
areas such as the Karotegin and Zebunisso areas. Climate and disaster-proofing measures 
identified during project design will increase the resilience of water supply services and sanitation 
systems.  
 
2.  The project will provide additional support to the ongoing institutional strengthening 
activities to improve the operations and maintenance (O&M) and financial management, billing, 
and commercial practices. It will continue supporting the establishment of a performance-oriented 
management information system with the use of supervisory control and data acquisition  system 
for operational efficiency and geographic information system for asset management and for 
efficient monitoring of district metered areas  and improved operational and business efficient 
service delivery by the State Unitary Enterprise Dushanbevodokanal (DVK). 
 
3.  The project will improve network management and leak detection practices and foster the 
use  of  performance-based  interventions  for  asset  inventory,  leak  detection,  and  small 
replacement works carried out by both DVK teams and small private service operators. It will also 
build the capacity of DVK on the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) emergency response and 
immediate  actions,  and  on  water,  sanitation,  and  hygiene  (WASH)  awareness  and WASH 
targeted programs and measures for vulnerable people and women. The establishment of a 
women’s training and empowerment center is proposed as a specific project gender-focused 
output. The center will provide vocational, leadership, and business skills trainings to create the 
necessary opportunities to help women realize their full potential and improve employment 
opportunities for women working in DVK, the Dushanbe City Administration, and other groups. It 
will also encourage the education and skills training of young women. Moreover, the center will 
provide counseling, rehabilitation, and shelter services for victims of gender-based violence.  
 
4.  The total project cost is estimated at $38.00 million, of which $35 million will be financed 
from the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Special Funds resources (Asian Development Fund 
[ADF]), $3.0 million will be financed by the ADF 13 Thematic Pool, and $3.80 million will be 
financed by the Government of Tajikistan toward financing of taxes and duties, land acquisition 
and resettlement costs, if required. Climate adaptation investment is estimated to cost around 
$2 million. The ensuing grant and the transaction technical assistance (TRTA) are listed in the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) country operations business plan for Tajikistan, 2020-2022.2

II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
5.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) grant will help the government to prepare the 
project scope, institutional and capacity development needs, and conduct due diligence for the 
technical, financial, economic, social, and environmental viability of the proposed investment 
project. CDIA will update and prepare the technical feasibility and preliminary engineering design 
of  the  project.3 The  TA consultants  will  prepare the  project,  a  capacity  development  plan, 
safeguards  documents,  project  procurement  risk  assessments,  mitigation  measures, 
procurement  plan  and  packages,  financial  due  diligence  of  the  project,  including  financial 
management assessments of EA and IAs as well as other operators who might be involved in the 
project through assets management programs, financial analysis and evaluation, detailed cost 
estimates for the project, and other arrangements to ensure that the ensuing loan complies with 
ADB and government requirements. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
6.  Output 1: Feasibility study for ensuing project prepared. This output will deliver the 
feasibility study and preliminary design for the proposed investment project. The activities will be 
conducted by the CDIA team in coordination with the TA technical experts and they will: (i) update 
the 2017 CDIA project feasibility study4 and prepare the preliminary design along with detailed 
cost estimates of the proposed scope, and include the design of the women’s center; (ii) provide 
technical support to the ongoing project management design and supervision consultant  to 
strengthen  the  project’s  detailed  design  and  bidding  documents;  (iii)  update  the  current 
institutional capacity assessment, and complement the institutional capacity development plan for 
DVK with additional non-revenue water (NRW) reduction performance-based initiatives, WASH 
awareness programs and targeted measures for vulnerable people and women, and COVID-19 
emergency response actions. The institutional assessment will include financial management 
assessment of all entities involved in the project, financial analysis and evaluation of the proposed 
project. ADB is the administrator of the CDIA assignment as it is financed from ADB regional TA 
resources.5CDIA will supervise its consultants and facilitate the collaboration with the ADB project 
 
team.  
 
7.  Output 2: Project preparation and due diligence for ensuing project completed. The 
ADB project team will be responsible for the project preparation and update of the due diligence 
of the proposed project based on the updated CDIA feasibility study, financial due diligence and 
preliminary design. This output will ensure that the project is prepared with a high degree of 
adherence to ADB’s due diligence requirements. The ADB project team will: (i) prepare economic  
(ii) validate and update CDIA detailed cost estimates and a financing plan, (ii) validate and update 
CDIA’s  financial  due  diligence,  including  financial  analysis  and  evaluation,  project  viability 
analysis, financial management assessments of all entities involved in the project, including the 
preparation of the financial management action plan, financial sustainability assessment of 
executing and implementing agencies and other operators directly involved in the project, and 
design of funds flow, accounting, auditing, and financial reporting arrangements; (ii) complete 
social,  environmental,  climate  and  disaster  risk,  resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples  due

guidelines; (iii) undertake poverty, social and gender analysis and prepare related action plans 
and frameworks; (iv) conduct and update project procurement risk assessment and prepare a 
procurement plan; and (v) conduct labor assessment as part of the social analysis so as to ensure 
that  any  potential  labor  risks  can  be  proactively  addressed  through  contract  and  contract 
management. 
 
8.  Output 3: Project management and implementing agency capacity strengthened. 
This output will strengthen the capacity of the implementing agency to improve project readiness, 
project implementation, and urban service delivery. These activities will provide capacity-building 
training to enhance project management, contract management, and realization of environmental 
and social safeguards. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $505,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-VII), and (ii). parallel financing of 
$100,000 will be provided on a grant basis by Cities Development Initiative for Asia to prepare 
the technical feasibility and preliminary engineering design of the project (footnote 2) and financial 
due diligence, including financial management assessments of all entities, financial analysis and 
evaluation and detailed cost estimates. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
10.  The government’s contribution is estimated as $5,000. The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space where available, communication 
facilities for consultants, and other in-kind contributions. The government was informed that 
approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing program or project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  ADB will administer the TA. The Urban Development and Water Division of ADB’s Central 
and  West  Asia  Department  will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate  consultants;  and  organize 
workshops. The Local Executive Authority of Dushanbe City will be the executing agency, while 
the DVK will be the implementing agency. To promote local participation and commitments, the 
TA will follow participatory consultations with a wide range of stakeholders for designing the 
project.

13.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.6 The TA will finance approximately 17.5 person-months of international 
consultant inputs and 19 person-months of national consultants services from a total of 13 experts, 
of which 4 will be engaged through individual consultant recruitment (the international team leader, 
the national deputy  team leader, international gender specialist, and WASH international expert), 
while the rest of the team will be engaged through a firm. Lump-sum payments and/or output-
based contracts will be considered for consulting services under the TA when appropriate.The 
 
TA consultant will support the preparation of the proposed project.  
 
E.  Governance 
 
14.  The  TA  will  update  a  project  procurement  risk  assessment  of  the  executing  and 
implementing agencies and financial management risk assessment of the implementing agency 
and  other  entities  directly  involved  in  the  project,  including  the  assets  management,  and 
recommend timebound financial management action plan indicating mitigation measures as 
needed and agree those with the EA/IAs. The TA will undertake economic analysis, financial 
management assessment, financial evaluation, and financial analysis, risk assessment and 
management plan. The TA will undertake safeguards screening and categorization results and 
prepare  safeguard  documents  on  environment,  involuntary  resettlement,  and/or  indigenous 
peoples.
